column2: The little fellow will grow up.
column3: The little fellow will grow up.

column2: Of what clay is he made?
column3: Of what clay is he made?

column2: Of the first mud that comes to hand.
column3: Of the first mud that comes to hand.

column2: A handful of dirt, a breath, and behold Adam.
column3: A handful of dirt, a breath, and behold Adam.

column2: It suffices for a God to pass by.
column3: It suffices for a God to pass by.

column2: A God has always passed over the street Arab.
column3: A God has always passed over the street Arab.

column2: Fortune labors at this tiny being.
column3: Fortune labors at this tiny being.

column2: By the word "fortune" we mean chance, to some extent.
column3: By the word "fortune" we mean chance, to some extent.

column2: That pigmy kneaded out of common earth, ignorant, unlettered, giddy, vulgar, low. Will that become an Ionian or a Boeotian?
column3: That pigmy kneaded out of common earth, ignorant, unlettered, giddy, vulgar, low. Will that become an Ionian or a Boeotian?

column2: Wait, currit rota, the Spirit of Paris, that demon which creates the children of chance and the men of destiny, reversing the process of the Latin potter, makes of a jug an amphora.

column2: CHAPTER V--HIS FRONTIERS
column3: CHAPTER five-HIS FRONTIERS

column2: The gamin loves the city, he also loves solitude, since he has something of the sage in him.
column3: The gamin loves the city, he also loves solitude, since he has something of the sage in him.

column2: Urbis amator, like Fuscus; ruris amator, like Flaccus.
column3: Urbis amator, like Fuscus; ruris amator, like Flaccus.

column2: To roam thoughtfully about, that is to say, to lounge, is a fine employment of time in the eyes of the philosopher; particularly in that rather illegitimate species of campaign, which is tolerably ugly but odd and composed of two natures, which surrounds certain great cities, notably Paris.
column3: To roam thoughtfully about, that is to say, to lounge, is a fine employment of time in the eyes of the philosopher; particularly in that rather illegitimate species of campaign, which is tolerably ugly but odd and composed of two natures, which surrounds certain great cities, notably Paris.

column2: To study the suburbs is to study the amphibious animal. End of the trees, beginning of the roofs; end of the grass, beginning of the pavements; end of the furrows, beginning of the shops, end of the wheel-ruts, beginning of the passions; end of the divine murmur, beginning of the human uproar; hence an extraordinary interest.
column3: To study the suburbs is to study the amphibious animal. End of the trees, beginning of the roofs; end of the grass, beginning of the pavements; end of the furrows, beginning of the shops, end of the wheel ruts, beginning of the passions; end of the divine murmur, beginning of the human uproar; hence an extraordinary interest.

column2: Hence, in these not very attractive places, indelibly stamped by the passing stroller with the epithet: melancholy, the apparently objectless promenades of the dreamer.
column3: Hence, in these not very attractive places, indelibly stamped by the passing stroller with the epithet: melancholy, the apparently objectless promenades of the dreamer.

column2: He who writes these lines has long been a prowler about the barriers of Paris, and it is for him a source of profound souvenirs.
column3: He who writes these lines has long been a prowler about the barriers of Paris, and it is for him a source of profound souvenirs.

column2: That close-shaven turf, those pebbly paths, that chalk, those pools, those harsh monotonies of waste and fallow lands, the plants of early market-garden suddenly springing into sight in a bottom, that mixture of the savage and the citizen, those vast desert nooks where the garrison drums practise noisily, and produce a sort of lisping of battle, those hermits by day and cut-throats by night, that clumsy mill which turns in the wind, the hoisting-wheels of the quarries, the tea-gardens at the corners of the cemeteries; the mysterious charm of great, sombre walls squarely intersecting immense, vague stretches of land inundated with sunshine and full of butterflies,--all this attracted him.
column3: That close shaven turf, those pebbly paths, that chalk, those pools, those harsh monotonies of waste and fallow lands, the plants of early market garden suddenly springing into sight in a bottom, that mixture of the savage and the citizen, those vast desert nooks where the garrison drums practise noisily, and produce a sort of lisping of battle, those hermits by day and cut throats by night, that clumsy mill which turns in the wind, the hoisting wheels of the quarries, the tea gardens at the corners of the cemeteries; the mysterious charm of great, sombre walls squarely intersecting immense, vague stretches of land inundated with sunshine and full of butterflies,--all this attracted him.

column2: There is hardly any one on earth who is not acquainted with those singular spots, the Glaciere, the Cunette, the hideous wall of Grenelle all speckled with balls, Mont-Parnasse, the Fosse-aux-Loups, Aubiers on the bank of the Marne, Mont-Souris, the Tombe-Issoire, the Pierre-Plate de Chatillon, where there is an old, exhausted quarry which no longer serves any purpose except to raise mushrooms, and which is closed, on a level with the ground, by a trap-door of rotten planks.
column3: There is hardly any one on earth who is not acquainted with those singular spots, the Glaciere, the Cunette, the hideous wall of Grenelle all speckled with balls, Mont Parnasse, the Fosse aux Loups, Aubiers on the bank of the Marne, Mont Souris, the Tombe Issoire, the Pierre Plate de Chatillon, where there is an old, exhausted quarry which no longer serves any purpose except to raise mushrooms, and which is closed, on a level with the ground, by a trap door of rotten planks.

column2: The campagna of Rome is one idea, the banlieue of Paris is another; to behold nothing but fields, houses, or trees in what a stretch of country offers us, is to remain on the surface; all aspects of things are thoughts of God.
column3: The campagna of Rome is one idea, the banlieue of Paris is another; to behold nothing but fields, houses, or trees in what a stretch of country offers us, is to remain on the surface; all aspects of things are thoughts of God.

column2: The spot where a plain effects its junction with a city is always stamped with a certain piercing melancholy.
column3: The spot where a plain effects its junction with a city is always stamped with a certain piercing melancholy.

column2: Nature and humanity both appeal to you at the same time there.
column3: Nature and humanity both appeal to you at the same time there.

column2: Local originalities there make their appearance.
column3: Local originalities there make their appearance.

column2: Any one who, like ourselves, has wandered about in these solitudes contiguous to our faubourgs, which may be designated as the limbos of Paris, has seen here and there, in the most desert spot, at the most unexpected moment, behind a meagre hedge, or in the corner of a lugubrious wall, children grouped tumultuously, fetid, muddy, dusty, ragged, dishevelled, playing hide-and-seek, and crowned with corn-flowers.
column3: Any one who, like ourselves, has wandered about in these solitudes contiguous to our faubourgs, which may be designated as the limbos of Paris, has seen here and there, in the most desert spot, at the most unexpected moment, behind a meagre hedge, or in the corner of a lugubrious wall, children grouped tumultuously, fetid, muddy, dusty, ragged, dishevelled, playing hide and seek, and crowned with corn flowers.

column2: All of them are little ones who have made their escape from poor families.
column3: All of them are little ones who have made their escape from poor families.

column2: The outer boulevard is their breathing space; the suburbs belong to them.
column3: The outer boulevard is their breathing space; the suburbs belong to them.

column2: There they are eternally playing truant.
column3: There they are eternally playing truant.

column2: There they innocently sing their repertory of dirty songs.
column3: There they innocently sing their repertory of dirty songs.

column2: There they are, or rather, there they exist, far from every eye, in the sweet light of May or June, kneeling round a hole in the ground, snapping marbles with their thumbs, quarrelling over half-farthings, irresponsible, volatile, free and happy; and, no sooner do they catch sight of you than they recollect that they have an industry, and that they must earn their living, and they offer to sell you an old woollen stocking filled with cockchafers, or a bunch of lilacs.
column3: There they are, or rather, there they exist, far from every eye, in the sweet light of May or June, kneeling round a hole in the ground, snapping marbles with their thumbs, quarrelling over half farthings, irresponsible, volatile, free and happy; and, no sooner do they catch sight of you than they recollect that they have an industry, and that they must earn their living, and they offer to sell you an old woollen stocking filled with cockchafers, or a bunch of lilacs.

column2: These encounters with strange children are one of the charming and at the same time poignant graces of the environs of Paris.
column3: These encounters with strange children are one of the charming and at the same time poignant graces of the environs of Paris.

column2: Sometimes there are little girls among the throng of boys,--are they their sisters?--who are almost young maidens, thin, feverish, with sunburnt hands, covered with freckles, crowned with poppies and ears of rye, gay, haggard, barefooted.
column3: Sometimes there are little girls among the throng of boys,--are they their sisters?--who are almost young maidens, thin, feverish, with sunburnt hands, covered with freckles, crowned with poppies and ears of rye, gay, haggard, barefooted.

column2: They can be seen devouring cherries among the wheat.
column3: They can be seen devouring cherries among the wheat.

column2: In the evening they can be heard laughing.
column3: In the evening they can be heard laughing.

column2: These groups, warmly illuminated by the full glow of midday, or indistinctly seen in the twilight, occupy the thoughtful man for a very long time, and these visions mingle with his dreams.
column3: These groups, warmly illuminated by the full glow of midday, or indistinctly seen in the twilight, occupy the thoughtful man for a very long time, and these visions mingle with his dreams.

column2: Paris, centre, banlieue, circumference; this constitutes all the earth to those children.
column3: Paris, centre, banlieue, circumference; this constitutes all the earth to those children.

column2: They never venture beyond this.

column2: They can no more escape from the Parisian atmosphere than fish can escape from the water.
column3: They can no more escape from the Parisian atmosphere than fish can escape from the water.

column2: For them, nothing exists two leagues beyond the barriers: Ivry, Gentilly, Arcueil, Belleville, Aubervilliers, Menilmontant, Choisy-le-Roi, Billancourt, Mendon, Issy, Vanvre, Sevres, Puteaux, Neuilly, Gennevilliers, Colombes, Romainville, Chatou, Asnieres, Bougival, Nanterre, Enghien, Noisy-le-Sec, Nogent, Gournay, Drancy, Gonesse; the universe ends there.

column2: CHAPTER VI--A BIT OF HISTORY
column3: CHAPTER six-A BIT OF HISTORY

column2: At the epoch, nearly contemporary by the way, when the action of this book takes place, there was not, as there is to-day, a policeman at the corner of every street (a benefit which there is no time to discuss here); stray children abounded in Paris.
column3: At the epoch, nearly contemporary by the way, when the action of this book takes place, there was not, as there is to day, a policeman at the corner of every street (a benefit which there is no time to discuss here); stray children abounded in Paris.

column2: The statistics give an average of two hundred and sixty homeless children picked up annually at that period, by the police patrols, in unenclosed lands, in houses in process of construction, and under the arches of the bridges.
column3: The statistics give an average of two hundred and sixty homeless children picked up annually at that period, by the police patrols, in unenclosed lands, in houses in process of construction, and under the arches of the bridges.

column2: In a relative measure, and in spite of the souvenir which we have just recalled, the exception is just.
column3: In a relative measure, and in spite of the souvenir which we have just recalled, the exception is just.

column2: While in any other great city the vagabond child is a lost man, while nearly everywhere the child left to itself is, in some sort, sacrificed and abandoned to a kind of fatal immersion in the public vices which devour in him honesty and conscience, the street boy of Paris, we insist on this point, however defaced and injured on the surface, is almost intact on the interior.

column2: It is a magnificent thing to put on record, and one which shines forth in the splendid probity of our popular revolutions, that a certain incorruptibility results from the idea which exists in the air of Paris, as salt exists in the water of the ocean.
